componenttext: If I'm not wrong, the volume targets that you set at the analyst meeting were x disposals x acquisitions. I know there's been a lot of moving parts here, obviously, with California and other stuff, but do we need to reset the target outlook allowing for the fact that I guess, we didn't meet the full year target here without acquisitions? Or can you reiterate the numbers that we had at the analyst meeting for future growth x acquisitions?

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the big change is that the gas price hasn't met so far. And what we'd hoped for where we'd be at this point. So I would view the acquisitions as a replacement for the gas production that we're probably not going to get next year from the Rockies.
componenttext: I think the big change is that the gas price hasn't met so far. And what we'd hoped for where we'd be at this point. So I would view the acquisitions as a replacement for the gas production that we're probably not going to get next year from the Rockies. So I think next year's guidance is probably pretty good.

componenttext: That's what we're looking for, and right now we don't have a reason to change that. But I'd caution you about the gas. The gas in the Rockies is the only place we're I'm feeling a little seasick right now.

componenttext: I don't know but we have two rigs running currently, and we had planned to go to double that next year and I don't think we'll do that. So whatever growth we've shown there, I think, is probably at some risk and so I think from my perspective, acquisitions is like drilling money. You move the money around and I think the acquisitions will cover that but in a different way.

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: For California performances, is there a simple math that we can do in terms of the numbers of rigs running relative to the production and kind of spin that forward? Are there any pitfalls that you'd want us to know, in terms of making that math for how ea
componenttext: For California performances, is there a simple math that we can do in terms of the numbers of rigs running relative to the production and kind of spin that forward? Are there any pitfalls that you'd want us to know, in terms of making that math for how each...

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's no simple math because I've been unsuccessful in doing the simple math, so even complicated math is difficult. It just depends on how fast they get the wells down and where they drill them and how they get their permits and where they get them. Ri
componenttext: There's no simple math because I've been unsuccessful in doing the simple math, so even complicated math is difficult. It just depends on how fast they get the wells down and where they drill them and how they get their permits and where they get them. Right now I'm being fairly cautious about it in our outlooking process. I'm always hopeful that they'll do better but right now we'll stay with a fairly cautious view of it for the short term.

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Yes. Eventually the permits come through. It's just a matter of when. I think we were probably a little optimistic about or maybe a lot optimistic about how fast we'd get them.

componenttext: It started as an experiment. And experiments work by chance. Usually experiments fail. And so the price we got, we paid for the other three quarters, was attractive, so we'll drill this out. If we can enter cheaply, we will. Certainly not an area where we're heavily focused.

componenttext: No. Some of the wells are oil wells, legitimate oil wells. So the amount of gas that’s produced is relatively small in the total and so I said flattish. That's what I would look for given the outlook right now. We actually are drilling real oil wells, not condensate wells.

componenttext: I guess the final thing would be: just as you race to the Elk Hills gas plant, can you be a little more specific on the new plant of 2012's start-up? But as I understand it, the gas gathering system has been the problem. Could you be a little bit more specific as to what the issues are being? What you're doing about it? headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our ability to predict this has not been all that exciting. So our goal is to get everything working. As we try to run the plant, there's some problems on the gathering system at the traditional oil fields. And we're working and see if we could make that
componenttext: Our ability to predict this has not been all that exciting. So our goal is to get everything working. As we try to run the plant, there's some problems on the gathering system at the traditional oil fields. And we're working and see if we could make that better. So I'd take a cautious view right now to improvements.

componenttext: My question is on corporate government and specifically, the press release that the board put out last week related to the incentive compensation plan. And on this point, Steve, I wanted to see if you can provide a little clarity on what the new total shareholder return incentives are, which I think you guys called TSRIs? And whether they are different from the previous plan and if so in what way? Or are they similar?

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: IWell, total shareholder return is simple. You take the stock price at the time these awards are put in place and three years later, you see how you compare with the 12 companies that are in a peer group. You include dividends in those calculations. And
componenttext:
I
Well, total shareholder return is simple. You take the stock price at the time these awards are put in place and three years later, you see how you compare with the 12 companies that are in a peer group. You include dividends in those calculations. And that's how you get, at the end, looking at your number one, two et cetera.

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's a table in the disclosures which will show you how it works, but it's basically more -- the old plan was on a quartile essentially. This plan is done incrementally so if you were the top one in this plan, it's the only way to get out for three yea
componenttext: There's a table in the disclosures which will show you how it works, but it's basically more -- the old plan was on a quartile essentially. This plan is done incrementally so if you were the top one in this plan, it's the only way to get out for three years out of the 12. It's the only way to get 2x so the plan is a lot steeper and more difficult to achieve than the old one.

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I've done the arithmetic correctly, your recent acquisitions, it sounds like about 50 million feet a day is natural gas. And my question is, were you intentionally buying natural gas? Or did you have to accept some natural gas to get the oil that you w
componenttext: If I've done the arithmetic correctly, your recent acquisitions, it sounds like about 50 million feet a day is natural gas. And my question is, were you intentionally buying natural gas? Or did you have to accept some natural gas to get the oil that you wanted?

headline: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We view all these things as sort of money, not whether it's natural gas or oil, and in our view, if you could buy natural gas and essentially, the present worth based on current prices, we wouldn't view that as an unattractive thing to do. You got to pay
componenttext: We view all these things as sort of money, not whether it's natural gas or oil, and in our view, if you could buy natural gas and essentially, the present worth based on current prices, we wouldn't view that as an unattractive thing to do. You got to pay $6 an M [MCF] baked into it, we view that as sort of unattractive. So buying gas in the current market discounted where basically sort of $4 discounted for present worth, we don't view it as an attractive thing to do. We produce a fair amount of gas. While we're oily, we're not a pure oil company and especially in the Permian. And a lot of opportunities, we think, in the Permian for gas we're a big processor of gas in the basin. So yes, we prefer to buy oil real cheap but if we can buy gas cheap, we'll do that to in our operating areas.
